text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: I wanted to have that conversation with you. Patient: Uh hum. Sure. And this is the PSA level; you’re also saying we need to see something on the CT scan, right? text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: My approach would be as we discussed last time to wait until that PSA level goes above one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But if we don’t. text: Patient: Yeah.This may not be a question for you. But if I were to retire- Doctor: Mhm. Patient: I'm not sure. I'm not sure what kind of health care insurance I'm gonna have. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Patient: Yeah, but, is so I don't know have you- I don’t know how to ask the question. So is there assistance available? If I would need it if I changed to a different insurance. Doctor: You mean as per trial or in general Patient: Just in general, I guess. Doctor: Yeah, I think you know, before you make any switch, I would say we touch base, have you touch base with our financial counselors to make sure that you're optimized with everything. I mean, you know, trying to think how old are you? Patient: How old am I? Patient: The older you get the harder it is to remember. I'll be 64 in November. Doctor: So when you qualify for Medicare, is it now or you have to be 65? Patient: I'm the lazy investor.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
